review_blob: 12-oz can, muled back from an OC retailer who pulled it off the truck seconds before selling it; about as fresh as I can get this beer in Seattle. Thanks, K! Pours a cloudy medium amber with bright orange gradient highlights at the edges. Sudsy off-white head that sticks around. Bright tangy citric and tropical nose with a little resin; showing mostly grapefruit and a bit of mango with resin underneath. Just a little bit of malty caramel. Creamy medium body with lively carb. Light caramel under a steady wash of grapefruit, mango, and resin. Long dry resiny finish. Nice one.
beer_name: Pizza Port Swamis India Pale Ale

review_blob: Draft at Tippe and Drague. Pours a cloudy pale orange-y amber with a sudsy white head. Big citric nose, lots of grapefruit and orange. Creamy light body with lively carb. Lightly toasted caramel, bit of carbonic bite, lots of grapefruit and orange on the mid palate. Long dry bitey finish.
beer_name: Fat Heads Sunshine Daydream Session IPA

review_blob: Draft at Tippe and Drague. Pours a cloudy medium amber with a sudsy white head. Mild sweet caramel nose with a bit of herbal hop. Creamy medium body with lively carb. Lightly toasted caramel with herbal hop mid palate. Solid.

Draft at SB. Pours a murky dark amber with a dense and creamy off-white head that sticks around for quite a while. Big sweet nose, lots of heavy pineapple and intense caramel. Creamy thick body with moderate carb. Very sweet mid palate, showing tons of caramel and pineapple. Flavors are appealing and well showcased, but could be a bit clearer. Long sweet finish, a bit cloying.

Draft at SB. Pours a murky dark amber with a dense and wooly tan head that sticks around forever. Nice big hoppy nose, showing light pine and grass notes on top of some sweet malty caramel. Creamy medium body with lively carb. Caramel and pine on the attack through the mid-palate, where an iced tea note starts to creep in. Finish is a bit acetic, a bit too much crystal malt.

12-oz can. Thanks, N! Pours a cloudy medium amber with a loose white head. Bright tangy hop nose, nice grapefruit and citric acid combo, also some pepperiness from the grains. Creamy medium body with lively carb. Bright grapefruit tang on the mid palate, also peppery malt notes. Dry finish. Freshness must really matter with this one; it was quite good.

750, capped (I think). Thanks, N! Pours a cloudy medium amber with a loose white head. Dry summer hay and some light tangy lemon on the nose. Creamy medium body with lively carb. Hay, grass, lemons, and a tiny bit of grapefruit on the mid palate. Long crisp finish.

22 (I think). Cant remember who brought this one (N?), but thank you. Pours an opaque dark ebony with a long-lasting creamy tan head. Big coffee and dark chocolate nose. Creamy thick body with moderate carb. Roasty coffee and dark chocolate mid palate, nice bitter counterpoint to the sweetness of the malts. Long roasty finish.

750, capped. Thanks, R (I think)!. Batch 3. Pours a cloudy medium amber with a loose white head. Tangy funk on the nose, some earthy caramel notes. Creamy medium body with lively carb. Tangy, earthy funk and caramel on the mid palate. Pleasant and drinkable but not spectacular.

750, capped. Thanks, J! Pours a cloudy dark brown with a scant tan head that fizzes away. Big sweet nose, lots of cinnamon and chocolate and oak. Creamy thick body, soft carb. Mid palate is heavily sweet, lots of chocolate and cinnamon playing against the oak. Cloying finish.

750, capped. Thanks, N! Pours a cloudy dark bluish amber with a loose white head. Big tangy berry nose, nice clear blueberry character. Creamy medium body with soft carb. Berries on the mid palate, gets a bit synthetic tasting toward the finish, maybe a little back sweetened? Tasty and fun to drink for sure though.

750, capped. Thanks, J! Pours a cloudy dark ebony with a loose whitish head. Light funky tang on the nose, with oak, berries, chocolate. Creamy medium body with lively carb. Oak, light tangy funk, berries, and chocolate on the mid palate. Very cool combination for sure.

650 (I think), capped. Thanks, R! Pours a cloudy dark ebony with a loose off-white head. Sweet soft berry nose. Creamy medium body with lively carb. Berries and light ferment tang on the mid palate. Wonderful beer. Soft dry finish.
beer_name: Wicked Weed Medora Blackberry Raspberry Sour

review_blob: 750, corked and capped. Thanks, M! Pours all over the table as soon as you pull the cork. Murky dark brown with a thin white head. Tangy basement nose, stale cereal. Watery thin body, carb is shot. Basement and irritation on the mid palate. This one was a loss.

750, corked and capped. Thanks, M! Pours a cloudy medium amber with a loose white head. Light caramel and a bit of vague grassiness and some light pencil shavings on the nose. Creamy medium body, soft carb, goes a bit watery in spots. Light caramel and pencil shavings mid palate. Earthy finish.

750, capped. Thanks, J! Pours a cloudy pale orangey-amber with a loose white head. Bright tangy nose, light funky basement, lemons. Creamy medium body with lively carb. Basement, lemons, light foresty notes that are kind of airy and almost a distant cousin to mint, but theyre just a fraction of the flavor profile. This one is mostly ferment character.

750, capped. Thanks, J! Pours a cloudy medium orangey-amber with a loose white head. Big sweet nectarine nose. Creamy medium body with lively carb. Juicy, dripping fruit flavors across the mid palate through to the finish. Tastes like biting into a nectarine. Light acidic bite, tartness dialed right in. Completely delicious and refreshing.

650 (I think), capped. Thanks, R! Wow, this one is so, so rad. Pours an opaque near-ebony with a loose and creamy tan head. Big coconut and chocolate nose, smells like a candy bar thats getting warm. Creamy medium body, almost light in body. Milk chocolate, cocoa, dark chocolate, and mountains of toasted coconut on the mid palate. Tastes like a Mounds or something for sure, but never gets heavy or cloying with sweetness. Really beautifully done.

750, capped. Thanks, J! Probably was the beer of the day. Pours a cloudy medium gold with a loose white head. Big sharp forward nose of raspberries and a hint of cranberry tartness; very clear aromatics. Creamy medium body with lively carb. Sparkling clean fruit flavors on the mid palate, tangy raspberries, very juicy, some tart accents with maybe pie cherry or cranberry overtones. Very powerful and still quite refreshing.

750, corked and capped. Thanks, M! Pours a cloudy medium amber with a loose white head. Sweet tangy nose, some caramel and maybe bits of coriander. Creamy medium body with soft carb. Caramel and pencil shavings mid palate. Pencil shavings on the finish.

750, corked and capped. Thanks, M! Pours a cloudy medium amber with a loose white head. Toasty cereal, light lemon, and a bit of earth on the nose. Creamy medium body with lively carb. Cereals, lemon, and some basementy notes on the mid palate. Interesting and refreshing.

750, corked and capped. Thanks, M! Wish you could have enjoyed all these yourself of course, but we would like to think we did you proud by taking care of them well and enjoying them socially. This one pours hazy pale gold with a loose white head. Light funky lemon and maybe a bit of basement on the nose, kinda flabby and closed out with a bit of laundry there as well. Watery thin body, minimal carb. Laundry and a bit of funk on the mid palate. Probably did not benefit from years and years in the cellar. Curious what it might be like fresh.

750, capped. Thanks, J! Pours an opaque dark purple with a billowing, sudsy pink head. Looks almost exactly like a tulip full of Welchs grape juice. Big tangy dark juicy berries on the nose. Creamy medium body, carb is a bit velvety. Silky shots of berry juice all over the mid palate, only moderately tart by DGBC standards. Very refreshing and drinkable.

750, capped. Thanks, J! Pours a cloudy medium gold with a loose white head. Sharp and crystal clear apricots forward on the nose, backed with crisp lemon and a tiny bit of tonic water. Creamy medium body with lively carb. Sharp, juicy, dripping fruit flavor on the mid palate, like biting into an apricot. Long crisp tangy finish.

750, capped. Thanks for legging out the work to get this one, N! Pours a cloudy medium gold with a loose thinnish white head that lasts. Bright nose, showing fresh apricots and some juicy vinous berries and oak. Creamy medium body with lively carb. Sweet cereal, apricots, and vinous berries on the mid palate. Certainly a wonderful beer, but not remarkable for fruit power or clarity in the flavors--more of a cohesively integrated beer than an explosively flavorful one.

750, capped. Thanks, N! Pours a hazy to cloudy medium gold with a loose and sudsy whitish head. Bright tangy nose, mostly lemony, not crazy funky, some sweet cereal. Creamy medium body with lively carb. Light lemon tartness on the mid palate, some toasty grain, some wet grass. Very refreshing, very nice.
beer_name: Oddwood Ales Taming the Savage Heart

review_blob: 750, capped and foiled. Thanks, J! Pours an opaque dark brown with a thin tan cream on top. Humongous bourbony nose, almost like a shot in a glass, very heavy caramel and apricot and vanilla. Pretty out of balance barrel character. Creamy thick body with minimal carb. Sugary mid palate, lots of overripe tree fruit, and then heaps and heaps and more mountainous heaps of bourbon. Long bourbony finish. Bourbon!
beer_name: The Bruery Bourbon Barrel Aged 7 Swans a Swimming

review_blob: 750, capped and foiled. Thanks, J! This was, um, a fun prank I guess. Pours a cloudy dark amber with a fizzy cream on top that goes away. Thin honey and stale sugary cracker nose. Creamy, slightly sticky thinnish body with moderate carb. Overly sweet and somehow stale-tasting mid palate. Gummy finish.

750. Thanks, J! Youre a stud. Pours a cloudy medium amber with a loose off-white head. Big tangy nose, tiny hints of basement, some vinous lemon, nice grassy esters. Creamy medium body with lively carb. Softly toasted grains under a nice blend of vinous lemon, grassy notes, and a hint of basement on the mid palate. Crisp finish. Really a nice one.

750, capped, foiled. Thanks, J! Pours a nearly opaque dark brown with a dense and creamy tan head that sticks around. Molasses, roasty grains, sweet smoke, and dark chocolate on the nose. Creamy heavy thick body with sluggish carb. Chocolate, roast, molasses, and smoke on the mid palate. Long sweet finish. Not a lot of single malt scotch character here, at least not in any dominating way. Its nicely coherent.
beer_name: The Bruery Poterie (Scotch Whisky Barrel Aged)

review_blob: 750, capped. Thanks,J! Pours a murky dark brown with a dense and creamy light tan head that lasts. Big chocolatey sweet oaky nose, very balanced and coherent--no syrupyness or overripe fruit. Creamy medium body with moderate carb. Chocolatey oaky mid palate, nice roasty grains, beautiful smooth body. Lovely beer.

750, corked and baled. Its ridiculously interesting to find a Unibroue Ive not yet tried. So cool that theyre still making new stuff--I probably just needed to be reminded to go look for it. Pours a murky dark brown with a gigantic, surging, pillowy off-white head that rocks and rolls around in the glass until all the way after the beer is gone. Not a geyser at all, though, despite being served above cellar temp. Popped like a shot when the cork came out, though. Put that all together and youre expecting something good before the glass even settles. Nose shows big malty caramel notes along with some soft plum and red apple skin notes. Creamy medium body with surprisingly moderate carb. Mid-palate shows beautiful fruits and malts, but unfortunately lapses into an aluminum note at the finish. Bummer. Thankfully, this goes away after it off-gasses for about half an hour, so be patient with this one if that aluminum tang drives you nuts (it certainly drives me nuts). Long fruity, softly sweet finish.

beer_brewer_name: Port Brewing Co / The Lost Abbey
review_blob: 22. Im sure this has lost some points for nothing but the fact that it has been around for a minute, and is probably not a newly-made bottle (correct me if theyve continued to crank out batches, though). Pours a cloudy medium amber with a dense and creamy off-white head that sticks around for a while. Citrus is there on the nose, a bit dialed back now, pine has gone soft and herbal, not quite to rosemary but not really a forest anymore either. Creamy medium body with lively carb. Toasty caramel under a steady light flow of apricots and grassy pine. Mild finish. These beers are all good, but months-old is certainly not the time for them to shine--still, shows really well despite the age.

beer_brewer_name: Port Brewing Co / The Lost Abbey
review_blob: 22. Pours a cloudy medium amber with a dense and sudsy off-white head. Big fresh bold grapefruit nose, light melon in the background. Grapefruit is very pithy and rindy, bitter. Creamy body on the high side of medium, plenty of carb. Lightly toasted caramel under a steady grapefruit wash. Very drinkable and repeatable, even with high intensity in the flavor profile.
beer_name: The Hop Concept Galaxy & Comet IPA

review_blob: Draft at SB. Pours an opaque black with a dense and creamy, initially sudsy burnt tan head. Sweet nose, chocolate, caramel, some candy bar. Creamy thick body with sluggish carb. Chocolatey sweet mid palate with caramel and candy bar notes. Sweet finish.

Draft at SB. Pours a cloudy darker medium amber with a dense and foamy whitish head. Big floral potpourri nose, the coriander is way out of balance here, by orders of magnitude. Acetic dry body, soft carb. Light caramel under an overwhelming wash of spices, seriously tastes like potpourri soaked in tonic water. I am thinking they used the wrong size measuring spoon for the spices or something, this couldnt have been what they intended.

Draft at SB for the 4-20 total tap takeover. Pours a cloudy pale amber with a loose white head that lasts a bit. Big grapefruit and resin nose. Creamy medium body with lively carb. Grapefruit and resin on the mid-palate, over a base of light caramel. Mild finish.

Cask at SB. Chilled overnight, mounted on the bar for service--slightly chillier than cellar temp, but not by much. Cloudy pale gold with a sudsy white froth on top. Mild fruity nose, some oranges and grapefruits and light pine. Not so cheeva-like, but thats alright. Creamy light body, minimal carb. Light malt sugar caramel under a nice floral herby hop charge on the mid palate. Crisp light finish. Gotta love offbeat american ipas served via gravity.

Draft at SB. Pours a cloudy medium gold with a loose white head that sticks around. Big sweet nose, a bit floral and perfumey, some light green herbs. Creamy heavy body, wooly carb. Light sweet grains and caramel underneath floral and herbal notes on the mid palate. Long sweetish finish.

Draft at SB. Pours a clear medium gold with a loose white head that sticks around. Light crackers and grass on the nose. Creamy light body with soft lively carb. Very dry finish--gets you right back in the mood for another sip as soon as you finish a sip. This is a clean, balanced, flavorful pilsner thats a bit bigger than a standard pale but not heavy at all. Good food beer or refresher. Gotta be an improvement on batches from years ago, though I dont recall ever trying older batches.

Draft at SB. Pours pitch black with a dense and creamy tan mousse that falls away quickly. Big sweet chocolatey cocoa nose, showing milk chocolate and bittersweet baking chocolate along with sweeter cocoa notes. Graham crackers there, and some roasty malt. Creamy thick body, seriously moves like chilled hot cocoa drink (minus the marshmallows). Mild sluggish carb. Roasty sweet in perfect balance on the mid palate--chocolate and cocoa notes playing off roasty malt notes harmoniously. Long dry roasty finish, never quite gets ashy. Nice one.
beer_name: Fort George From Astoria With Love

review_blob: Draft at SB. Brewing this was probably a humongous PITA, but they really need to make this all the time. So rad. Pours a cloudy medium golden amber with a loose white head. Piercingly acidic citrus nose, bright clean sweet mandarin notes far above all. Creamy medium body with lively carb. Bright tangy citrus notes with a tiny bit of pepper offsetting them, very balanced and coherent and crystal clear. Great beer.
beer_name: Black Raven Flock Party Anniversary Ale

review_blob: Draft at SB. Pours a cloudy dark brown with golden amber edges. Odd cinnamon nose, with toffee and caramel. Creamy flat medium body. Cinnamon, toffee, and caramel mid palate. Not sure what happened here. By and large, these guys still quietly produce some of the better beer around these parts.

Draft at SB. Pours a clear dark golden amber with a thin whitish head that goes away fairly quickly. Big corn and fusel nose. Creamy medium body with lively carb. Corn, fusel, and a bit of a scorched note on the mid palate, finishes with a faint burnt flavor. These guys have done some nice stuff and I dont think one batch is reason to bag on them, but this one needs a bit more attention.

beer_brewer_name: Melvin Brewing Company (Thai Me Up Restaurant & Brewery)
review_blob: Draft at SB. Pours a crystal clear orangey medium amber with a dense and creamy whitish head that lasts quite a while. Big grapefruit nose with some apricot. Creamy medium body with lively carb. Lightly toasted caramel, grapefruit, and some apricot on the mid palate. Long dry finish. Nice one.

Draft at SB. Pours a hazy pale gold with a dense and creamy whitish head (first couple pours out of the keg were positively turbid, but then it poured clear the rest of the night). Sweet herbal hoppy nose, green and leafy and kitcheny. Creamy medium body with lively carb. Herbal hoppy crisp mid palate with mild biscuity flavors under. Crisp finish.

375 (I think) corked and foiled tall skinny bottle. Pours a deep crystal clear crimson. Minimal head or lace. Big apple cough syrup nose. Sticky thick gooey body. Tastes and moves like apple cough syrup.
beer_name: Etienne Dupont Cidre De Givre Eis Cider

review_blob: Draft at SB. Pours a crystal clear medium amber with a dense and creamy tannish head. Big bright nose, showing lots of depth and complexity--caramel under, plus bright grapefruit and pine and a bit of sweet herbs. Creamy medium body with lively carb. Lightly toasted caramel on the mid palate, tons of crystal clear grapefruit and pine and herbs on the mid palate. Very tasty and refreshing.
beer_name: Firestone Walker Luponic Distortion Revolution No. 001

beer_brewer_name: Melvin Brewing Company (Thai Me Up Restaurant & Brewery)
review_blob: Draft at SB. Pours a cloudy medium amber with a towering dense and creamy off-white head that lasts and lasts. Big sweet nose, lots of mango and pineapple and caramel and spicy notes. Sticky thick heavy body. Caramel, fruits, and spices on the mid palate, gets a bit hot and dry near the finish.

12-oz can. Pours a hazy pale gold with a thin off-white head. Sticky sweet artificial nose, some rubbery plastic there as well. Watery light fizzy body. Heavy sweet artificial sugary mid palate, also showing some rubbery plastic. Heavy sweet finish. Like drinking Mountain Dew out of an old tire.
